dialogues.text: Well, I thought I'd seen it all, but I have to admit "I didn't do it, he did" "No I didn't" "Yes he did" -- that's a new one even to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just come in and talk to him with me -- then decide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll represent him no matter what. We have to.  But fine-- (as they go in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only have a caseload that high sitting on my desk while I waste a whole afternoon here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first thing we hear is reggae music: Bob Marley's "Jammin", with a male voice that can't really sing, singing along.  Then we PAN along the office -- a royal mess -- books, papers everywhere -- a poster of the BILL OF RIGHTS with "NULL AND VOID WHERE PROHIBITED BY LAW" stamped across it in red letters.  We finally come to a big, bear-like figure in an ex-hippie's khaki shirt and jeans -- late thirties, with a beard and an oversized stogie, skankin' around the office.  This is GARY SCHWEICKART.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a Jamaican accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, my client, Jah Skank Irie, is innocent. For it is not the ganja weed that is on trial here today, only the man... mon. JUDY burst in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary, put down what you're doing and get your ass down to Franklin with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Jamaican accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa -- don't get your knickers in a twist -- you'll give yourself one of them aneurisms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious, Gary.  I think you should see this. She dumps her notes on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drops the accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Milligan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh uh.  Sorry, Judy, one of the perks of getting to be the boss is you don't have to give up all your free time representing the Campus Rapist if you don't want to.  And I don't want to.  Besides, I already met him before I ordered the psychiatric evaluation, and he specifically asked for a female lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, she knows he's  gonna like this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he does, his eyes twinkle, he loves a challenge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not guilty?  They got enough hard evidence to lock him up till doomsday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leans in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, Billy Milligan did not commit those rapes.  At least come down and talk to him. A beat.  GARY leaps up, grabs his beret to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDY, GARY and BILLY.  BILLY has withdrawn completely int himself -- eyes half-closed, his lips moving in some internal conversation.  JUDY looks at GARY, who just sits there -- skeptical and impassive.  Finally, BILLY opens his eyes and is suddenly infused with the same belligeren energy he had while talking to DR. EDMUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Judy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Ranger Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Gary Schweickart.  He works with me in the Public Defenders office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy, Bob. GARY smiles tightly.  He doesn't like him right off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember meeting him briefly when you first came in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a face you forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that you requested a female attorney, but Gary's the most qualified...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't request nothin'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Billy did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, someone did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitates Gary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, someone ain't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And have we met before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  You came in with one of the headshrinkers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And at that time you answered to the name Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all do.  Saves time.  But that don't mean we like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright... Tommy... we'd like to ask you a few questions.  How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much time do you spend as Billy? Were you there when he got out of the straitjacket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that was me.  Billy couldn't get out of a wet paper bag.  I can dislocate my shoulder to slip it down to where I can loosen the ties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you learn to do that? BILLY looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got somethin' else you wanna know or can I leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Please.  How many of you live there with Billy? BILLY smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than three?  More than five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not really sure.  A lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you there when... whoever you were at the time was arrested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  That was Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny's the keeper of pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: College man, Bob?  Ivy League? GARY steams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means whenever Billy's in any pain, Danny comes onto the spot to take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spot?  What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ... it's not my job to answer all these questions.  I'm outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, wait... Tommy... But BILLY has retreated into himself once again.  Eyes glazed and half-closed -- lips moving silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what you dragged me here for in the middle of the day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. In a moment, BILLY "returns" -- but now he sits with impeccable posture, his fingertips pressed together in front of him.  He speaks in clipped, precise tones with a perfect Knightsbridge English accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must apologize for Tommy's impudence.  He gets frustrated from being locked up.  My name is Arthur. How do you do? JUDY and GARY exchange a look.  He ain't buying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do? JUDY looks again at GARY, who half rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, how are ya...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, understandably, I've been better.  But Tommy said you have some questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Gary was asking about the arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police found an arsenal of weapons in your apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing to do with those. The only one permitted to handle guns is Ragen.  He's the Keeper of Rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He used those guns when he kidnapped and raped those three women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icily calm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragen never raped anyone.  He committed the robberies because we were skint, but he denies, absolutely, having anything to do sexually with those women.  And of the many things he undoubtedly is, a liar is not among them.  All our lives people have accused us of being liars.  It's become a point of honor never to tell a falsehood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you don't always volunteer the truth, then that's lying by omission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come now.  As an attorney, you know very well a witness is under no compulsion to volunteer information he hasn't been asked for.  You would be the first one to tell a client not to elaborate unless it was in his best interest. But why don't you meet Ragen and ask him yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't Ragen the one who pulled the toilet from the wall and threw it at the guards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's learned to control his flow of adrenaline.  It gives him unnatural strength. (playfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't worry -- he won't hurt you. Unless, of course, he feels threatened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright... Arthur -- I'd like to meet him. BILLY smiles -- then gets up and moves his chair to the far side of the room -- putting as much distance between himself and them as possible.  He sites back down and the retreats once more.  Eyes look down -- lips move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much education has he had?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much.  Some high school.  D average.  I.Q.'s a hundred.  He paints, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paints?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Portraits, landscapes.  He's good. Then, BILLY'S back.  He seems bigger -- hulking -- crouched like a wary fighter.  The tension in his facial muscles change his appearance.  His eyes squint narrowly, giving them a piercing quality -- his brow beetles.  And he speaks in a thick, Slavic accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who called me a liar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little unnerved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said the evidence indicated that someone in there raped those three woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admit three robberies near university.  But other things you say I do is a lie.  And if we go to jail, I'll kill the children.  Jail is no place for little ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What little ones?  There are children there with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you killed the little ones... wouldn't that also mean your own death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are all different people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when you get hurt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because Danny is the Keeper of Pain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.  Danny is empath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Billy knows nothing about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has amnesia.  Arthur and I keep him asleep to protect him. Depending on circumstances, either I rule or Arthur does.  In prison, I control spot because is dangerous place.  As protector, I have complete command.  In situations where is no danger, and where intelligence and logic are more important, then Arthur controls spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mentioned the spot, too.  Can you describe to us just what that means. Billy?... Uh... (he looks to Judy for help)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragen. But suddenly, RAGEN is gone.  JUDY and GARY look at each other.  There is none of the usual lips moving and quasi R.E.M. state.  He's just blank.  Then, in a moment, he "returns".  He seems tentative, frightened, softer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. No reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we met?  My name is Judy Stevenson.  This is Gary  Schweickart.  We're your attorneys. Do you have a name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy. She looks at GARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes. She looks back to BILLY.  His eyes seem to wander and dar back and forth of their own volition, like an ocular pendulum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As GARY and JUDY come out.  GARY immediately lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either he's a multiple, or else he's the greatest liar anybody's ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question is which is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (convinced)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary... As they talk, WE CUT TO: BILLY alone in his empty cell, eyes half-closed, lips moving silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's facing hard time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got one right handed personality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of people are ambidextrous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragen speaks and writes prefect Serbo-Croation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do ten million Serbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently, Arthur's fluent in Arabic and Swahili.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having a facility for languages doesn't automatically make you one hand short for bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The escape artist, the wandering eyes, the electronics expert... GARY and JUDY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of that can be mastered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All by one person?  With a hundred I.Q.?  From a small farm in Ohio? You're looking for some kind of miraculous, inexplicable "thing" to prove this to you beyond a shadow of a doubt.  Well, it's an illness, Gary... not a magic trick.  And I believe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs heavily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do, too.  And I feel like I can convince my wife of it when she asks me why I came down here for fifteen minutes, and came back five hours later.  But how in hell am I ever gonna convince a judge?  Or a prosecutor?  No one's ever been acquitted of a crime before by blaming it on another personality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't have to.  He will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY sits on his cot in a cold sweat.  Something is clearly terrifying him.  He looks across the cell toward piece of steel over the sink shiny enough to serve as a mirror.  He is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a big, opaque, steel door with a small opening two thirds up in the middle.  A GUARD approaches with keys. There's a loud rumbling coming from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Milligan.  Exercise time. As he turns the key:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hour in the yard, all to yourself. As he opens the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on... Milligan... Now we see BILLY lying in a pool of blood on the floor. The sink is smashed into a million pieces and his wrists have been slashed lengthwise with a shard of porcelain. Hot water shoots from the blood-stained sink like a firehose gone haywire.  He meant business.  He's fainted and landed on his own arm, which is saving his life.  The GUARD runs in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help!  We got an emergency!  Quick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY lies in bed, staring off blankly, while GARY and JUDY talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya feelin', Billy?  You were out for quite some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where you are?  You're in the hospital, but you're gonna be just fine.  Your hearing is going to go ahead as scheduled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why don't you get some rest. We'll check in with you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Billy. He remains motionless.  They leave and we follow them int the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  But there were no hammers or crowbars in that cell with him.  He broke that sink with his bare fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEMBERS OF THE ADULT PAROLE AUTHORITY, JUDY, BILLY and A PROSECUTOR, along with a COURT STENOGRAPHER and TWO POLIC OFFICERS.  BILLY'S wrists are bandaged.  GARY enters, obviously agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just found out they're gonna try and send him to jail for a parole violation and keep him there till the trial.  We need him in a hospital with doctors for those ninety days to build a case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parole violation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's a statute of limitations and this is the last day they can nail him on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods to the Prosecutor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Yavitch?  Shall we begin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, members of the Adult Parole Authority, the state moves that possession of an unregistered firearm is a direct violation of the defendant's parole, and he should therefore be remanded to Lebanon State Prison until trial date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection, Mr. Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Schweickart -- don't you own a tie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disheveled as usual)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do, your honor, but I like to save it for funerals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your objection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are these the weapons that were found in the defendant's home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, Mr. Schweickart knows damn well that they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, Mr. Schweickart does not know damn well that they are because Mr. Schweickart has yet to see any ballistics report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weapons have not been test fired yet, you honor, so the report has not been completed.  But I fail to see in what way that is prescient to the decision at hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winging it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is "prescient" counsel, because without any proof of it's ability to propel a ballistic, this... "thing" is not a gun, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on, Schweickart, of course it's a gun. (to the Chairman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a gun.  Obviously it's a gun. GARY grabs it and holds it to his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Schweickart... JUDY and BILLY duck -- the PROSECUTOR finches -- but GARY pulls the trigger.  It's unloaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Legally, until it shoots a bullet it's as much a gun as it is a zucchini.  And having zucchinis found in your apartment is not a violation of Mr. Milligan's or anybody else's parole.  Mr. Chairman, gentlemen, since the statute of limitations of Mr. Milligan's alleged parole violation is up today.  I move that the defendant be allowed to stay at Harding Hospital, under the supervision of a trained psychiatric staff until it is time for him to stand trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman... The CHAIRMAN raps his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So be it.  Next time get your shit together, counsel. Shakes his head, chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zucchinis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is escorted from a police car by TWO UNIFORMED OFFICERS.  He is handcuffed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An admitting nurse signs a release form, accepting delivery of BILLY with a big ORDERLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take those off him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not while he's still ours. She finishes, they uncuff him.  To the nurse:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I give you a little advice? Keep him away from the toilets.  Let him piss in a bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, the NURSE and the ORDERLY walking down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Harding's not here right now, but he'll look in on you as soon as he arrives. As they walk, they pass people who are obviously deeply disturbed, as well as TWO FEMALE PSYCH-TECHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after they've passed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna stand for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a con.  It's a lousy con.  And I'm not gonna treat him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is alone.  He looks at the door.  An eye is watchin him through the peephole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PSYCH-TECH sits on a stool, watching him and taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: THE NOTES
dialogues.text: 5:00 Sitting cross legged on bed, quiet. 5:15 Sitting cross legged on bed, staring. 5:32 Standing, looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY sits, alone and sullen, while other PATIENTS either smoke, play cards or stare into space.  Another YOUNG MAL PATIENT sits next to him.  He's got a tin of peanut brittle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want some?  My folks bring it.  Your folks come visit you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My folks are divorced.  Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?  Come on, what's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sympathetic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only they call you Billy, right? But that's not your name, is it?  I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do that all the time here. (offers his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie Wood.  How do you do? BILLY shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Harding Hospital.  BILLY attached to an EEG, while a TECHNICIAN looks at the results.  He's obviously confused

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: on the print out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Harding.  The TECHNICIAN is showing the printout to a DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got to be a mistake.  A glitch in the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never had a problem before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you want me to say? Adults do not emit spiked Theta waves on their EEG's.  Only children do.  Try changing the electrode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TWO DOCTORS are administering another EEG to BILLY. They seem satisfied with the results this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?  Completely normal.  Those electrodes are for shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I didn't change the electrode. I had to order it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCTOR HARDING approaches BILLY'S peephole and peers in. Beside him is the ADMITTING NURSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is on the floor, drawing.  He's made a very disturbing picture of a tombstone that's inscribed: DO NO R.I.P.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's looking forward to meeting you, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gulps a little)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see him in my office.  Lots of coffee, please. He heads off down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is dropped off by an ORDERLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rises to greet him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Billy, come on in.  Sit down. Coffee? The ORDERLY leaves, closing the door and shutting us out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's small and sterile.  The JUDGE, PROSECUTOR, STENOGRAPHER, DR. HARDING, GARY, JUDY and BILLY are present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor, based on my interviews with the defendant, it is my opinion that, William S. Milligan suffers from Multiple Personality Disorder and has fragmented into ten separate personality manifestations.  At the time of the acts in question, I believe he was mentally ill and unable to distinguish between right and wrong.  Further, he did not have the ability to refrain from committing these acts.  These findings are consistent with a plea of not guilty by reason of insanity, and I would, therefore, recommend that he be remanded to Athens State Hospital for suitable treatment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Yavitch, do you contest these findings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, your honor.  The prosecution does not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, lacking any evidence to the contrary, this court has no alternative than to find the defendant not guilty by reason of insanity. He raps his gavel three times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is led, handcuffed, by TWO POLICEMEN, out a back entrance, but they still collide with a handful of REPORTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel now that you've been found not guilty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel better now that it's all over with and I finally have come back to a reality that I've missed for so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any recollection of the crimes your other personalities have been charged with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very little.  Certain things come to me in forms of dreams that you could call memories, but I can't really distinct between memories -- the realities...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside to another Reporter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.  And I'm Doris Day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... because my emotions split so far apart -- love, hate and fear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, what do you want to do with your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Become a citizen again. The COPS lead him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY sits in back, flanked by the TWO POLICEMEN.  It's freezing cold.  They're bundled up -- BILLY wears just a suit.  One POLICEMAN drinks hot coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you got away with it, didn't ya?  You must be pretty proud of yourself. BILLY shivers silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You turn my stomach.  I've got two daughters.  Come on, you can tell me -- you're fakin', right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray... (to Billy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look cold.  You want some hot coffee?  Here. The SECOND POLICEMAN, who wears thick gloves, purposely shoves the cup at BILLY'S handcuffed hands so that the coffee spills all over his lap, scalding him.  The POLICEMEN laugh. Out the window, BILLY realizes they're passing by a turn off on the road marked by a covered bridge.  He gets upset. WE PRESS IN on BILLY.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 1958, and filled with middle aged JEWISH COUPLES out for the resort's Saturday night entertainment.  The MEN are in suits and the WOMEN are dressed to the teeth -- falls attached to over-teased hair, false eyelashes and stiff, heavy gowns.  Minks draped over chairbacks. Spotlights roam the stage and the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen.  The Eden Roc Hotel welcomes you to the Grand Ballroom.  Have we got a show for you tonight! PRESS IN on BILLY, AGE THREE. He's in a suit and bowtie, on a stool next to the kitchen entrance, watching the stage in rapt fascination.  WAITER and BUSBOYS rush past him loaded down with trays full of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire and Myrna -- the Barry Sisters... (applause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dancing stylings of Tanya and Briaggi... (applause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, please welcome the adults only comedy of Johnny Morrison.

dialogues.speaker: THE STAGE
dialogues.text: Over applause, the band plays JOHNNY'S lead-in music.  He bounds on stage, all sweat and smiles -- his old shirt collar too tight for his extra chin.  But the spotlights keep roaming -- leaving him in the dark.  He gives a "can you believe this shit?" face and the audience reluctantly plays along.  This is the oldest shtick in the book.  Onc again, the band plays his little intro.  Once again the audience applauds -- but less than before.  And this time instead of the spots landing on him at the music cut-off, they focus on an empty spot across the stage.  Scattered laughter.  More groans.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: laughing hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you know why it's cheaper here than the Fountainbleu. Nothing.  No response.  Just chairs scuffling and forks o dessert plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between BILLY and the SPOTLIGHT, as JOHNNY continues with his act.  BILLY is fascinated by it: it's sharp, defined glow, lighting up just one perfect circle while all aroun it is darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two women at the Fountainbleu are looking through a hole in the wall into the men's steam room.  They see one poor shnook, naked as a jaybird with a towel over his face. The first woman says: "Ciel... would you look at that?  He's not Jewish." The other woman says "Jewish?  He's not even a guest here." Rimshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flop sweat now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, already. He whistles at the spot through his two fingers and motions it towards him.  It moves maybe a foot in his direction.  He commits the comic's cardinal sin -- he laughs when the audience doesn't.  He's the joke now.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: oblivious.  Laughing -- deliriously happy.  Suddenly, a BUSBOY with a tray full of glasses bangs into him and everything smashes to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cleaning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of the goddamn aisle.  I been just missin' you all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't see before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's too bad -- what the hell are you doin' in here all alone, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to Johnny)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Well, he stinks.  That steam room joke is as old as my Aunt Bessie's ass. He goes to lift BILLY off the stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now sit someplace else, before I have you thrown out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! TWO BIG HANDS -- more like paws -- enter frame and lift the BUSBOY off the ground.  They belong to a second BUSBOY, huge and mustachioed.  He speaks with a thick Slavic accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy, I was only...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just leave him alone. He tosses the FIRST BUSBOY aside like a piece of crumpled up paper and gives his attention to BILLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't see before.  That's my Daddy. He lifts BILLY up onto his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.  Now you see everything.

dialogues.speaker: THE STAGE
dialogues.text: as JOHNNY finally walks over to the spot and steps inside it.  A couple of people applaud.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: on the BUSBOY'S shoulders -- eyes glued to his FATHER -- all lit up against the blackness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY'S MOTHER, DOROTHY, is coming, watching a soap opera and talking on the phone all at the same time.  BILLY, still three, has a toy ambulance that he's running all over with -- rolling it over everything, making siren noises, "vrooming" at the top of his lungs.  Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, please -- can't you see I'm tryin' to watch the TV?  Now take that someplace else. He takes the car down the hall -- vrooming slightly quieter.  WE HOLD on a framed photo of JOHNNY MORRISON an JIMMY DURANTE.  Baby BILLY sits on DURANTE'S knee.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: arrives at a door leading to the garage.  He opens it and immediately starts coughing.  It's filled with fumes.  He looks inside the car, which is running, and sees his FATHER, slumped over on the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's filled with people, all in black, all eating.  BILLY is in a black suit and bowtie, getting underneath everybody's feet, still carrying his ambulance.  He vroom very quietly.  He looks over at his MOTHER, red-eyed from crying, on a sofa with another WOMAN.  DOROTHY breaks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, he looks just like him.  I can't look at him.  I can't... THE OTHER WOMAN quickly bustles BILLY away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, son.  Your Mother's very upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's empty as the WOMAN brings BILLY inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you just sit up here and play for a while, alright?  That's all grown up stuff goin' on downstairs. And soon your Mama's gonna take you back home with her to Ohio.  Won't that be fun? She leaves and closes the door.  He sits alone in the middle of the floor.  He spins the wheels of his ambulanc against the worn out rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, a siren)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wooooo... woooo... And he rolls it slowly out of frame.  Beat... beat... beat... it rolls back to him.  And it's been turned aroun to face him.  BILLY looks up and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to reveal a three year old GIRL, all in white.  She's the girl from the painting with the rag doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vrooom... vrooom...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: He rolls it back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a piano bar and DOROTHY is in a ratty, red sequined dress, singing "You're Nobody Till Somebody Love You." As she does, WE SEE BILLY, age eight, not really watching, just sitting sullenly -- blowing air bubbles in his Coke.  Someone's watching though.  CHALMER MILLIGAN sits at the bar, smiling at DOROTHY.  She starts performing just to him.  BILLY realizes what's going on and watches carefully.  CHALMER catches BILLY'S look and feels exposed.  He turns his attention back to DOROTHY.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: CHALMER and DOROTHY, laughing in a booth over drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to the next booth -- BILLY is fast asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of people and rides.  BILLY, DOROTHY and CHALMER are in line for one ride, but as they get to the gate:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, he's too little.  There's a height requirement. BILLY is stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Billy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tell ya what -- you wait here and we'll meet you right after. It's a short one, this one. He ushers DOROTHY onto the ride as BILLY steps aside -- watching and waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHALMER watches from the sofa as BILLY sits with crayons and a pad on the floor.  BILLY reaches for the red one, but CHALMER'S foot comes down on it.  A beat as BILLY looks up at him.  Finally, CHALMER lifts his foot and BILLY takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOROTHY is shaking BILLY out of a deep sleep.  She's breathless with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, wake up.  Look. She shows him an engagement ring on her finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked me to marry him.  We're not going to be alone anymore. She hugs him tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY and DOROTHY doing the dishes together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chalmer is your Daddy, now.  You call him Daddy Chal. BILLY looks into the living room at CHALMER, asleep in front of the TV, a beer in his hand.  CHALMER opens his eyes unexpectedly, startling BILLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doin' in there?  Only sissies help their Mama's do dishes. You come in here with me and watch some TV. BILLY is nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (privately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.  He's you Daddy, now.  You mind him.  He loves you. BILLY goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them at the dinner table.  No talking -- jus quiet eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, would you please pass the salt? He grabs it and goes to hand it to his MOTHER, but CHALME grabs his other wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salt gets passed clockwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything at the table gets passed clockwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because that's how we did it when I was growin' up.  It learned me manners -- you don't have everybody reachin' all over the table for everything -- gettin' in everybody's food. BILLY passes it clockwise, via CHALMER, who gives it to DOROTHY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just like when I taught you to sit with your hands on your knees and your feet flat on the floor when you're not eatin'.  And you don't have to know the reason for everything, anyway.  If I say to do something, then that's enough. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Daddy Chal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHALMER, BILLY and DOROTHY watching TV.  Ed Sullivan. CHALMER'S got a beer in one hand and his other arm is around DOROTHY as he starts fondling her breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling awkwardly, pulling away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chalmer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a hoarse whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...? He leans in to kiss her neck.  BILLY watches.  CHALMER looks right at him, then nuzzles her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still mindful of decorum)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (climbing on her now, but not really threatening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me no -- we're married now. He thinks he's being playful.  A hand inside her blouse. BILLY still watches in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catches Billy's look to Chalmer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? He looks at BILLY once more, then, never taking his eyes off him, slides his tongue into DOROTHY'S ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gets up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can go in the bedroom. She leaves and goes upstairs.  BILLY looks at CHALMER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking at? (an icy hiss)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bend them eyes while I'm talkin' to you, boy. BILLY looks down.  CHALMER drains his beer and tosses the empty can at him, then heads upstairs.  In a moment, we hear a hit.  DOROTHY screams.  Another hit.  BILLY sits closer to the TV -- turns up the volume.  A plate spinner on Ed Sullivan.  As the beating continues upstairs.  BILL changes the channel, landing on an old Basil Rathbone/Nigel Bruce Sherlock Holmes movie.  He stare har as Holmes performs some miraculous demonstration of deduction.  BILLY turns up the volume till it drowns everything else out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY sits drawing at the table while his MOTHER does the ironing.  The drawing is a landscape, and remarkably good for a nine year old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it that late?  God, I don't know where the time went. She leaves the room and heads upstairs.  As BILLY looks up, he sees CHALMER standing in the next room, staring at him.  BILLY goes back to drawing, but is unnerved.  He looks up again -- CHALMER is gone.  He tentatively leaves the kitchen and pads very slowly into the living room.  N one there.  BILLY sits on the sofa and looks up -- there' CHALMER, leaning against the wall next to the entrance way.  BILLY is startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Daddy Chal... No response.  CHALMER'S eyes bore a hole right through th boy.  BILLY picks up a magazine.  He leaf's through a couple of pages, consumed with fright, then puts it back carefully -- perfectly -- in the center of the coffee table.  He glances up.  CHALMER hasn't moved.  He's still staring.  BILLY puts his hands on his knees and his feet flat on the floor.  Then he gets up and exits the room from the opposite side where CHALMER is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As BILLY comes out of the house.  He goes into the yard and wanders restlessly -- tosses a stick.  He gathers all his courage and looks back towards the house.  There is CHALMER, watching him from the window.  Terrified, BILLY starts to cry silently.  Suddenly, his MOTHER'S voice startles him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy! She's at the upstairs window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on to bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY lies awake.  He's exhausted, but more scared.  Ever time he starts to nod off, he forces his eyes back open with a start.  He pinches his arm and twists hard to keep himself up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, eyes puffy from lack of sleep, sits opposite CHALMER and DOROTHY.  CHALMER doesn't look like he's slep much, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what I made for my two men this morning.  Pancakes and bacon and fresh squeezed juice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to the farm today, Billy.  There's a lot to be done. BILLY is gripped by fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY and CHALMER moving down a long, lonely road. Neither one says a word.  They both just stare straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it turns off one road and onto another -- this one containing the covered bridge.  It's the same one that adult BILLY passed in the police car.  A farm can be seen in the distance amongst the spindly, leafless trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHALMER sits on the ground, drinking beer and staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to include the corn crib from the charcoal animation. BILLY is locked inside, trying to ignore his step-father' stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY sees a cardinal on a tree branch.  He has some paints with him and starts to sketch out the bird on a piece of slate.  Suddenly CHALMER pops up in front of him carrying a shovel.  He unlocks the corn crib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on... He leads BILLY out and they walk off into a field as the cardinal flies away to freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is digging a long hole that's already knee deep. CHALMER sits and watches.  He holds a rusty, hollow, meta pipe in his hand -- about a foot long and four inches wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six feet.  You hear me? BILLY continues digging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHALMER pushes a rototiller, churning up the ground for the coming season. WE FOLLOW him as he goes.  Finally, he passes the pipe he was holding earlier -- only now it sticks up six inches from the ground.  As CHALMER rides out of frame we hear the amplified sound of shallow breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see BILLY only from the naked torso up.  Through a window, we can see CHALMER outside, drinking under a tree His pants are undone.  BILLY'S back is to us.  He's tied to the rototiller -- straddling it.  His eyes are wet from crying.  He struggles against the rope, but it's no use.  Then, his eyes fix into the middle distance.  He stares so hard, it hurts.

dialogues.speaker: A BRIGHT, WHITE LIGHT
dialogues.text: shining straight into our eyes.  At first it has no form, no perimeters.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: staring.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIGHT
dialogues.text: feels like a birth as we PULL BACK from its center, gathering velocity.  It rumbles, then roars, until we finally get to it's outer edge.  Now it has a shape.  It' a spotlight -- sharp, defined.  Surrounded by darkness. Like the spot that shone on Johnny Morrison at the Eden Roc.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: staring even harder.

dialogues.speaker: THE SPOT
dialogues.text: as a form emerges from it's deepest recesses.  It's human A teenage boy.  The figure stretches out it's hand.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Suddenly, he blinks -- like we've seen the adult BILLY do.  His entire face seems to change.  He's not terrified anymore, merely confused.  He reaches his face over to hi constrained hand and touches his cheek with his fingers. He has no idea why he's been crying.  He looks around the barn -- then out at CHALMER, who is oblivious.  BILLY looks at the rope around his wrists.  They are tied to each other, close together, but there's still some slack. He takes a beat, then uses one hand to push the thumb of his other hand far across it palm.  His eyes are clenched in concentration.  His hand turns beet red.  Suddenly, there's a snap and his thumb is successfully dislocated. With his thumb pulled out of its socket and draped across his palm, the thickest part of his hand is now thinner than his wrist, enabling him to slide it out from the rope.  He snaps it back in place and undoes his other wrist.  Outside the window, CHALMER is now passed out drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CARDINAL painted on the piece of slate.  It's been signed: BILLY.  BILLY is fully dressed now, rubbing his still red thumb, when he stumbles upon it.  He picks up the paintbrush next to it and adds some touches. Satisfied, he signs a second name beneath the one that's already there: TOMMY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a brilliant Fall day.  BILLY, age nine, is walking t school past an apple orchard.  He carries a big, shiny re apple -- polishing it as he goes.  He never sees the car that suddenly rounds the bend and heads straight for him. We hear a MAN and a WOMAN giggling drunkenly from inside -- completely oblivious.  It is virtually upon him, when, as if shoved from behind by an invisible force, BILLY is thrown clear of the automobile.  It crushes the apple int sauce and disappears around the next bend, but BILLY land safely.  He starts to cry.  Then we hear a voice.  It has a thick East European accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christene... BILLY looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... don't cry... I get you another apple.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: on a adult pair of hands as they shimmy up a tree trunk and grab an apple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, holding this new apple, walking happily to school once more.

dialogues.speaker: RAGEN'S FACE
dialogues.text: against a dark and indistinct background.  He's inspired by the Eden Roc busboy -- intense, olive-skinned, with a full black moustache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will always be here to protect you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, age twenty one, is working out with a set of nunchuks.  He handles them like an expert, like a killer. Sweat covers his bare chest.  His hands are a blur.  He punctuates each move with a throaty war cry, still in the thick Yugoslavian accent, as he uses a mannequin's face and torso to simulate the disarming and vicious pummeling of an attacker.  He ends with a fierce, sustained scream of a warrior.  When he comes back to himself, he looks down: the mannequin is in shreds.  He opens the refrigerator.  It's empty.  He grabs his wallet from his pocket and opens it.  It's empty.  He throws it angrily t the floor.  He goes to the sink and sticks his head under to wash the sweat off the get a drink, when the doorbell rings.  BILLY approaches it warily.  He keeps his accent all through this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy. BILLY grabs an M-16 from under a chair, reaches high on a shelf for a clip and pops it in, then holds it to his sid as he opens the door a few inches.  GORDY is eighteen, thin, pale and high as a kite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, it's cold.  You got any scotch? He starts to enter, but BILLY blocks his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?  We gonna do this in front of the neighbors?  I've got the money. GORDY takes out sixty bucks in crumpled bills.  BILLY looks at it, then lets him in.  GORDY walks past him into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking back, imitates him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I going? GORDY pulls out a dresser drawer and put it on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. GORDY reaches in and BILLY moves right for him, the gun barrel coming to rest on his back.  GORDY pulls out a cellophane bag that's been duck taped to the back of the dresser.  It's got several smaller bags inside, each stocked with a different supply of pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa.  Jackpot. He turns and sees the gun pointed straight at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?  I showed you the money. He tosses it to BILLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool it. But BILLY is stunned.  He's never seen the pills before. He lowers his gun and grabs the bag.  As he opens it and pulls out its contents:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you gettin' all excited for?  Have I ever ripped you off? Never.  Wow, you got the reds. BILLY drops the bag to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know this was there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking them up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where you always keep 'em. Oh no.  Are you gonna get all weird again?  I hate when you do this shit. GORDY pockets sixty dollars worth of speed, then sees the nunchuks and a set of free weights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you were so into that stuff. He picks up the nunchuks -- does a few comically inane moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he does)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, who put the bug up your ass today?  And what's with the commie accent?  You know, the guy I work for is looking for a bodyguard. Someone to drive the car to the pick-ups and look like an animal so no one pulls any shit.  You wanna meet him?  The pay is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- ask him.  The sumbitch is made of money.  I'm goin' over there now.  You wanna come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So come on.  His name's Foley. BILLY grabs a sweatshirt and they leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the water roars below, BILLY sits alone in his parked car.  Thirty yards away is a parked MERCEDES.  TWO MEN si in the front seat, while GORDY leans in the back window talking to FOLEY.  BILLY is tense, but stoic.  In a moment, GORDY turns.  He gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to talk to you. BILLY gets out of the car.  The other THREE MEN get out o theirs.  BILLY takes the long walk over, but upon reachin them one MAN spins him around to face the car while holding an automatic to his head and the OTHER starts to frisk him.  Immediately, BILLY elbows the MAN WITH THE GU in the throat, delivers a quick flurry of knifehand karat strikes to his face, breaking his nose, then holds him in front of his own body. dialogues.text: (to the two men)

dialogues.text: FOLEY presses a button and a bar opens.

dialogues.text: No shit.  Where'd you get a name like Milligan?

dialogues.text: Except one thing.  I do not hurt people unless my life is in danger, and I do not harm womans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GORDY'S taking a hit of speed and washing it down with a swig of vodka.

dialogues.text: Where'd you learn karate?  Who are you really?  Ex-C.I.A.?  Mercenary? But BILLY has drawn into himself -- lips moving silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost relieved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy. BILLY smiles and takes a pill.  After he swallows it, GORDY offers him the vodka.  BILLY reaches past him for a beer. GORDY shrugs and picks up a volume of poetry by Emily Dickinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poetry?  You read this shit?  Or you got a girlfriend I don't know about? BILLY has never seen it before.  GORDY reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope is the thing with feathers That perches in the soul, And sings the tune without the words And never stops at all. BILLY grabs it and throws it across the room.

dialogues.text: No?  Then who the hell's it belong to? The book has landed in front of a painting of the withdrawn, teenage girl with long pair parted in the middle. As we PRESS IN on BILLY, we CROSSFADE to:

dialogues.text: He's nine years old.  DOROTHY'S approaching voice wakes him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy!  you're gonna be late for school! She opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, come on. He looks at her, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.  I'm making blueberry pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bright, white light, surrounded by darkness.  PHIL is there, tucking a napkin into his collar.  He's a tough looking twenty year old with bad skin and three days of growth of beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, still age nine, tucking a napkin into his collar. He's smothering his pancakes in a ton of syrup and wolfin them down in huge, convict size bites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to show this report card to Daddy Chal.  One D, all the rest F's... What's wrong, Billy?  I know you're bright.  You go to school every day.  Why don't you learn?  It's like there's two Billy's.  And one of them I don't care for very much at all.  Now you're going to have to try and do better, and that's all there is to it.  Understand?

dialogues.text: Do you have any black coffee?

dialogues.text: It's very Eisenhower fifties mid-west.  Thanksgiving turkey cut-outs on the windows; Autumn leaf displays, etc The CHILDREN are all taking their seats.  BILLY doesn't know were he belongs.  He finally sits, but immediately, GIRL approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Haworth, Billy Milligan just swore at me and he's sitting in my seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... BILLY stands and the GIRL sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Billy?  Don't you remember where your seat it? He shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting very tired of this little game, Billy.  Now take your seat. By this time, there's only one seat left unoccupied. BILLY sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Now maybe we can get on with our arithmetic test. As MISS HAWORTH passes out the mimeographed quiz sheets, BILLY is gripped with fear.  He looks at the sheet.  It's like hieroglyphics to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright class, you may begin. The KIDS start work -- BILLY freezes.  A beat then:

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: on an adult hand, holding a pencil, poised over the test. We hear an English accent:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear, really.  You must be joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssh! BILLY sits with a completely different posture and demeanor.  He looks down his nose at the test and races through it.  He's done almost immediately and puts down his pencil.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAWORTH
dialogues.text: looks up from her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to include BILLY.  He's back to being himself -- scared and confused.  He has no idea how he got to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you even going to check your work? He doesn't respond.  She takes the paper and looks at it. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see your arms. He rolls up his sleeves.  Then she looks all around his desk.

dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extremely suspicious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a Saturday and there's no one around, except for BILLY, now age fourteen.  He's throwing rocks from about thirty yards away -- trying to break windows.  We're behind him as he hears PHIL'S twenty year old voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ANGLE on BILLY'S face, speaking as PHIL, with a thick New York accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Another ANGLE on BILLY'S face, answering as KEVIN -- also twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bustin' windows. An adult hand, picking up a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.  Let me.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: throwing a rock and shattering a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHIL, in the light, wiping the dirt off his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is baffled, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Kevin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Kevin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm standing on the hill -- behind the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KEVIN, now in the light.  He's twenty, blonde hair, green eyes -- a tough guy like PHIL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philip, what's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, KEVIN is lit in the spot.  In the F.G., PHIL in semi-darkness, is unaware of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a funny name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  I'd bust you if I could see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where ya live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY casually throws rocks at the school, breaking windows as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Kevin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Spring Street.  Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm from Brooklyn, New York, but now I live on Spring Street, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 933 Spring.  A white house. Owned by some guy named Chalmer Milligan.  He calls me Billy. KEVIN reaches down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: picking up a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez -- that's where I live.  I know the same guy.  He calls me Billy, too.  I play along for the pancakes. BILLY throws the rock -- then turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KEVIN turns, as BILLY just did, and comes face to face with PHILIP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't never seen you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't never seen you there, either.

dialogues.text: (popping open a Zippo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, shit, pal, let's go down to the woods and light fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.text: BILLY runs off towards the woods, Zippo in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, age twenty one, has discovered drugs stashed behin the dresser drawer.  He checks them out, then speaks with Arthur's British accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L.S.D.  Kevin and Philip have become undesirables.  Something must be done to banish them from the spot.

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: MUSIC blasts.  Elton John's "Madman Across the Water". The screen is filled with a wash of deep blue.  BILLY enters frame, silhouetted against it, paintbrush in hand. He attacks the blue with whites and yellows. In a SERIES OF CUTS: The painting is incredibly detailed -- fine, delicate lines forming eyes and strands of hair -- but his manner is frenetic.  He paces the floor, staring at the canvas the way a matador sizes up a bull, then hurls himself at it -- always reigning himself in to achieve the controlled, meticulous tension that the painting demands.

dialogues.speaker: THE SPOT
dialogues.text: ALLEN painting.  Cigarette dangling from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: THE PAINTING
dialogues.text: further along.  It's like a story unfolding.  Symbols, clocks, faces -- all corresponding to some private vision of BILLY'S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME CUT.  BILLY is drenched now.  He paints a section, then steps back to look at it.  Dissatisfied he takes a can of red paint and flings it across the canvas.  He stops a moment to catch his breath, then starts all over again.  In a moment, he "blinks".  His demeanor changes, his posture, the way he holds the brush.  He goes from looking like an artist in complete command of his craft, to looking like some guy holding a paintbrush.  He sees the bag of drugs ARTHUR had left out earlier and picks them up, hungrily.  From out of an envelope, he shakes ou a small piece of paper with a stamp of a loopy cartoon horse on it.  He smiles wickedly, then puts it to his tongue and licks the purple microdot off the tip of its muzzle.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: painting -- tripping out of his mind.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: now ALLEN, the personality who had originally started the painting.  He's looking aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHIL has turned it into some sixties psychedelic nightmar and signed it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: lights a cigarette, then starts painting over it -- starting again.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: painting in detail once more.  His neck is sore.  His fingers are sore.  It's pitch black outside.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: finally finished.  Ashtray overflowing.  He's looking at the result.  It is a major work -- complicated -- probabl over-complicated -- full of the confusion and enormity of what's inside him.  He signs it: ALLEN.  He wipes the sweat off his face, walks to the sofa and lies down.  He' asleep in seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY wakes up.  A beat.  He walks over to the painting. He looks at it, then reaches for a handful of crayons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three year old CHRISTENE picking up crayons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY stands stunned.  There are childish squiggles and drawings all over the canvas.  It's completely ruined. His eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a male figure moving through the shadows, though we can hardly discern any activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to include the spot in the distance.  RAGEN is in it.  In the foreground, now, the lurking male figure enters the frame.  We see him, only partially and from behind, watching RAGEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen year old BILLY is practicing pulling a knife fro his boot and chucking it at a tree with lightning speed and accuracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragen Vadascovinich. RAGEN turns quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY has his knife out in a defense stance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAGEN is in the same position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is all alone, talking to himself in the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (English accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the same body.  We share it.  You are in my head and I am in yours.  And there are others as well, but most of them don't know about each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR stands just outside the spot, talking to RAGEN. He's twenty two, with a patrician air and John Lennon glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is true -- I have heard voices before -- but how can you be same place I am?  Is not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's simple, really.  Whoever is on the spot holds the consciousness. Right now, it's you.  When it's someone else, we are very often unaware. RAGEN eyes him warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you play chess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAGEN and ARTHUR in a limbo-like space, playing chess. Though they are obviously sitting, we can see not chairs. It's like they are sitting in blackness.  In the background, we can see CHRISTENE, all of three years old, sitting in the spot, drawing happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we are to survive in the world, we will have to bring some order out of this chaos.  Billy wanders around, oblivious, starting things and not finishing them -- getting into all kinds of ridiculous scrapes -- switching in front of people.  And some, like Philip and Kevin are quite destructive and need to be carefully monitored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen year old BILLY and his class are taking a math test, but BILLY, currently occupied by CHRISTENE'S personality, is drawing pictures all over the test sheet. A GIRL sitting next to him is watching him incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR AND RAGEN
dialogues.text: playing chess.  CHRISTENE drawing in the spot in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, an Indian defense.  Very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that? He indicates a four year boy sitting alone, staring blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is Shawn.  He's completely deaf.  He takes the spot to block out his mother's cries.  We've got all kinds here.  But there's got to be a way of controlling things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Billy know about us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should he be told?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it would drive him insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how can things be controlled?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll make rules.  Everyone will have specific duties that are tailored toward their particular talents.  Tommy is an electronics genius, as well as an escape artist. Several of us are painters.  I excel at foreign languages and dabble in medicine and biochemistry.  The girls do domestic chores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are women here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.  April and Adalana.  They do the cooking, the shopping, the cleaning... checkmate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shall continue your role as protector...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen year old BILLY jogging -- sweat pours down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... developing yourself physically... learning the martial arts -- weaponry -- being able to step into a dangerous situation at a moments notice. He speeds up -- running harder and harder.  The intensity in his face is enormous -- as if every fiber of his being were perfectly focused on this one activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TEACHER is droning on, writing endlessly at the blackboard.  She has lost control of the class, which is chatting away, paying little or no attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The War of the Roses was a series of wars fought by two English families in the late 15th Century for the rule of the country. As she speaks, the class gets quieter and quieter in the background, until there's just the TEACHER and a strange whispering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The House of Lancaster had a red rose as its emblem while the House of York had a white rose.  The forces of the House of Lancaster won and their leader, Henry Tudor, father of the future Henry VII, became king... Finally, she turns around and stops speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to include class.  They are all staring at BILLY, age fourteen, who sits at his desk, eyes glazed and half rolled into his head -- lips moving a mile a minute -- whispering in a strange gibberish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign on his desk identifies him as such.  He faces BILLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know why you're here, Billy? Do you want to talk about it? BILLY looks away.  The COUNSELOR comes around his desk an sits close to BILLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can say anything here.  Go on. What are your feelings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like a dream that comes and goes.  My step-dad hates me.  I hear him screaming.  I hear other voices, too.  I get blamed for stuff I didn't do.  People call me a liar. I never know what time it is -- or what day it is.  Sometimes I feel like I'm going crazy.  I don't know what's in my pockets.  And I see lots of things that aren't real. There's a locked door and someone's pounding to get out.  I see a woman falling down and suddenly she's turning into a pile of metal and I can't reach her and I'm so scared and lonely and I'm afraid to ask for help.  I need help.  Oh God... (self-conscious, through sniffles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm the only kid who can take a trip without LSD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Billy.  We're going to get you some help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY being examined by a G.P. -- while his MOTHER looks on.  After a bit:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ears normal, eyes normal, throat O.K. -- I don't see anything yet. Alright, Billy, take off your pants. His face crumbles.  He's overcome by fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Billy, you mind the doctor. The DOCTOR reaches for BILLY'S belt, and BILLY screams in terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nooo!!! It echoes into eternity as WE CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY walking down a corridor with a different DOCTOR, leaving his MOTHER behind.  As they go, they pass all manner of disturbed children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Billy.  No one's going to hurt you.  We're here to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR gives BILLY two pills in a small, paper container.  BILLY puts them in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY taking different pills on a different day. The same day. And again.  Now he washes them down with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, DOROTHY and CHALMER, across the desk from the DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He certainly seems high strung, and his mood swings are unpredictable. He also likes to pretend or role play quite a bit.  But I don't really see that there's anything more we can do for him here.  Try changing his diet.  He seems to do better on Jello day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As BILLY walks through with his books, other KIDS point and whisper to each other.  Some laugh.  As he passes one little GIRL, she yells from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Milligan is a psycho!  He was in the loony bin! The KIDS laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's windy as all hell as BILLY inches his way towards th edge.  He's a million miles away -- his eyes fixed in the middle distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, with the very same expression, inside the spotlight.  We hear voices from around the periphery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must do something.  We must act now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Push him off the spot or he'll jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY still moving forward -- ever closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He appears to be walking -- but he doesn't move.  It's as if he's on a treadmill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh let him jump.  Who needs him around, anyway?  Always embarrassing us -- always getting us into trouble...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It's our responsibility to keep him safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY'S picking up speed now.  This is the final push.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY going fast -- still gaining no ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take spot.  Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he's trying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell with him.  Loser...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY at the edge -- about to jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! And now RAGEN emerges from the darkness, running full speed.  He tackles BILLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY suddenly throwing himself to the ground just a step before going over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAGEN and BILLY on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after catching his breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must put him to sleep, is too dangerous otherwise. ARTHUR emerges close enough to the light to be visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.  He can no longer function for himself.  He shall relinquish the spot indefinitely.  Even if it means he never wakes up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, on the ground, eyelids heavy, lips moving. Suddenly, he is still.  Then, his eyes open fully.  He gets up.  He's completely confused at being on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is now occupied by ALLEN, the fourteen year old, al alone in the light.  His confused expression is an exact duplicate of BILLY'S on the roof.  Somewhere in the B.G., a small girl laughs softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: into the surrounding semi-darkness, where RAGEN kneels before CHRISTENE, a finger to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssh.  Billy is sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as RAGEN indicates BILLY, lying in what we can only assum is a bed -- but the darkness is too thick to see below hi body.  He is fast asleep.

dialogues.text: which segues into a series of fluid images:

dialogues.speaker: PAINTINGS
dialogues.text: done by BILLY.  Portraits, still lifes, landscapes -- don and signed by different personalities, ending with a portrait of SHAWN.

dialogues.text: It looks like something out of Dante's Inferno.  Gigantic machinery, churning out sparks and steam, motored by propane and hydraulics.  The noise is deafening as huge, hook-covered ladders roll on suspended tracks and dip an endless supply of metal parts into a succession of electrified acid baths.  MEN duck and weave in goggles an huge, rubber gloves, narrowly avoiding decapitation or electrocution as they do their routines.

dialogues.text: standing at the operator's control panel.  It's a mystifying series of buttons, levers and speakers -- and BILLY is completely dumbfounded.

dialogues.text: He sees everything, but hears nothing.  Silence.  He is deaf.
