dialogues.text: Fuck security. A DOCTOR comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K., why don't you just settle down.  You've had a lot to drink. BILLY ignores him and heads down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody help me!  Anybody! SECURITY GUARDS head off after him, grabbing him by the arms, trying to wrestle the dog away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asleep in bed, covers pulled up to his chin.  He looks like he had a bad night.  His eyes pry open, one at a time.  It only takes a moment for him to realize something is wrong.  He looks down to the foot of the bed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as BILLY slowly pulls the covers up, revealing his bare feet.  They're caked in mud and wet grass.  The covers keep pulling.  His ankles are also filthy -- and somethin more: there's a trickle of dried blood.  He keeps pulling It's some grotesque true life parody of the horse's head in "The Godfather." BILLY is completely covered in blood. And he hasn't got any idea why.  He's fully dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is in a panic.  His shirt is off and he's trying to wash out the blood in the sink.  He scrubs it first with soap, then Comet and a brush.  Suddenly, FRANCINE is at the bathroom door, loaded down with groceries.  She stare in horror at what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away! He kicks the door shut in her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, what have you done?!  There's blood everywhere -- my God, Billy! The door flies open.  There's BILLY -- crazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the hell out of here and don't say a word to anybody. He goes back to scrubbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (near hysteria)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening to you?  I wake up scared every day.  Billy, I don't know if you're gonna be sweet or act crazy or sit and stare at the wall -- and I don't know if it's my fault or what I did wrong.  Tell me -- I can fix it.  Please... She stumbles to the closet, and pulls out the shoebox while he comes into the bedroom and puts the wet shirt over a chair to dry.  She emerges with the .38 in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you have guns, Billy.  You don't have to hide them.  I want to know where you've been getting all this money from?  New watches, new clothes -- you haven't held a job steady in six months!  Billy... Billy... She turns him around to face her.  His eyes are rolled up under his lids -- his lips going frantically.  He's oblivious to her as she pulls back in fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's empty.  Around the edges, ARTHUR, RAGEN, TOMMY, ALLEN, PHIL and KEVIN are in a frenzied argument.  In the distance, we hear FRANCINE continuing to speak to BILLY, trying to snap him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to break this off once and for all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did all the blood come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Arthur)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were supposed to dominate spot. Is your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying -- I can't keep control. The others steal time and I can't stop them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?  Would ya listen to him? He thinks he shits crumpets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Arthur)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we all listened to you we'd be sitting with our thumbs up our asses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be some code, some kind of order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must re-group.  And the first step is to eliminate her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't.  I won't let you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've nothing to say about it. ADALANA comes forward.  She's nineteen, with long, string black hair.  Her eyes drift with nystagmus.  She has a pathetic kind of gravity that shuts the others up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not fair.  You can't shut out the only love we have.  No one else touches us.  Feelings matter more than staying in control.  They matter more than anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without love we'll die. Behind her, we can see TOMMY has gotten into the SPOT and picked up the gun, which he now holds to his head and cocks.  The others don't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As FRANCINE watches in fear.  BILLY holds the cocked .38 to his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy... Billy, come on... He twirls it on his finger and puts the barrel in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy... you're scaring me... In one swift move, he aims and shoots out a lamp, darkening the room to an eerie glow.  FRANCINE screams as the bullet leaves a hole in the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the others argue.  RAGEN grabs the gun from TOMMY and takes the spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know rules!  Only I touch guns!

dialogues.text: BILLY angrily slaps the gun down on the desk.  He turns and paces as he rants:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Slavic accent)

dialogues.text: Things have gone too far.  I take control from now on. (English accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's not the solution... FRANCINE takes this opportunity to grab the .38 and run out of the apartment.  BILLY realizes and chases after her.

dialogues.text: FRANCINE a flight ahead of BILLY, running for her life.

dialogues.text: FRANCINE gets in her car and is frantically hitting all the buttons to lock the four doors as BILLY reaches her. He looks inhuman -- a maniac.  He's carrying a screwdrive and banging on the driver's side window with it, chipping the glass.  She turns the key and starts to pull away fro the curb, but BILLY jumps on the hood and starts frantically puncturing the windshield with the screwdriver.  Shards of glass fly into the car, whizzing past her face, cutting her forehead and cheek.

dialogues.text: (Slavic accent)

dialogues.text: Give me the gun!  Give me the gun! Terrified, she stops the car, opens the window just wide enough to fit the gun through.  He grabs it and she immediately rolls the window back up.  He jumps off the hood and stalks his way back inside as FRANCINE burst int tears.

dialogues.text: Fifty four years old, my first time on a plane... can you believe it? My daughter finally got me a ticket. She says let me do something for you.  I said if you really wanna do something for me, stop seeing that musician who gave your dog angina. The truth.  He played that damn guitar so loud, he killed the dog. dialogues.text: ARTHUR is in his glory.  BILLY wears a suit and bowler hat, and carries an umbrella.

dialogues.text: BILLY checks his vest pocket watch against the huge clock

dialogues.text: crossing Abbey Road.  He takes his shoes off first, reproducing the album cover.

dialogues.text: (greets him)

dialogues.text: The decline of the empire can be directly linked to disastrous labor policies since the war. dialogues.text: I've obviously returned just in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earth has not anything to show more fair Dull would he be of soul who could pass by A sight so touching in its majesty The city now doth, like a garment, wear The beauty of the morning... It's the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... He stops and takes his return airplane ticket from his pocket, looks at it a moment, then tears it into a dozen pieces.  He lets them scatter over the water like confetti.

dialogues.text: BILLY wakes up wearing pajamas in a Hampstead bed and breakfast.  He doesn't know where he is.  The bed is strange.  The room is strange.  Panicked, he goes to the window and looks out: double decker buses, big black taxicabs, all driving on the wrong side of the street.  H turns back to the room, sweating now.  He sees a suitcase and lurches for it.  He pulls out unfamiliar clothes, toiletries.  He finds his wallet.  It's filled with strange, colored money.  Then he sees a passport he doesn't remember obtaining.  The picture has him in a sui and a bowler.  He notices a United Airlines ticket envelope on the night table and opens it.  It's empty. He's verging on hysteria now as he runs out into the hallway and down a narrow flight of stairs, where he passes the PROPRIETOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bit of breakfast, then, gov'ner? It's included... But BILLY just tears past him, out the front door and int the street.  He paces the sidewalk, terrified and angry a the same time, ranting to no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?  What the hell am I doing here?  What's wrong with me? He falls down to his knees, tears streaming down now, and beats his fists into the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with me?  I want to die... please, God, let me die...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A UNIFORMED IMMIGRATION OFFICIAL is stamping BILLY'S certificate of deportation.  As a conversation goes on around him, BILLY zones out -- lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No passport, no money, no ticket home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not clever, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody Americans -- think they own the world.

dialogues.speaker: PRESS IN ON BILLY
dialogues.text: We hear a FEMALE VOICE inside his head.  It's insinuating manipulative.

dialogues.text: It's all your fault.  Everything. Our whole life is ruined and it's all because of him.  He has to pay for what he's done to us.  He has to die.  There are ways.  Things we can do to him...

dialogues.text: The one at the farm.  CHALMER is tied, shirtless, to a chair.  A lit blowtorch enter frame and comes straight at him.  CHALMER screams.

dialogues.text: APRIL nineteen, long hair, big, crazy eyes.  She has the blowtorch.

dialogues.text: BILLY heading home from England.  A UNIFORMED OFFICER sit beside him, but he's staring off.

dialogues.text: We could burn his body -- bit by bit -- so he'd never be able to hurt anyone again.  The heat would cauterize his wounds as we went, so there would be no blood.

dialogues.text: We'd keep him awake with amphetamines, so that he'd suffer here on Earth -- before he went to hell.

dialogues.text: BILLY is so intense by now, that the UNIFORMED OFFICER is looking at him funny.

dialogues.text: From the near darkness, APRIL whispers into RAGEN'S ear - like the snake convincing Eve to bite the apple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget what he did to the children.  To Christene... He has to be stopped.  He has to die.

dialogues.text: BILLY has a telescope, which he's taking apart.  He pulls two hairs from his head and carefully wets them to the inside of the eyepiece, which he's removed from the telescope.  He looks through it -- then glues the cross hairs in place.  He swigs from a bottle of Stoli.

dialogues.text: CHALMER MILLIGAN is getting ready for work: putting a large key ring on his belt, etc.  Of course, he's thirtee years older then we've last seen him.  He walks into the front hall, but, as he passes the mirror, a light flashes in the reflection, it blinds him for a split second.  He doesn't think much about it and goes for the hall closet door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flash of light.  It comes from the sun hitting the homemade telescopic sight that BILLY has mounted onto a carbine.  He's hiding behind a tree across the road, with the weapon aimed straight for CHALMER'S front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHALMER puts on his jacket, then his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY watching and waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHALMER, ready to go, reaches for the doorknob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorknob turns.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: starts to pull the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOORKNOB
dialogues.text: stops turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHALMER, his hand still on the doorknob, realizes he's forgotten something.  He leaves the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY suspended, waiting.  A car passes from out of nowhere.  The DRIVER looks over in BILLY'S direction. BILLY ducks behind a tree before he's seen.  His eyes hal close.  His lips move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAGEN in the light, holding the carbine.  ARTHUR emerges from the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHALMER, in his bedroom, retrieves his wallet from a dresser and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAGEN aiming the rifle once more, while ARTHUR pleads wit him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't kill him.  They'll send us to jail -- including the children. How do you expect them to survive in prison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will protect them.  He must be stopped so he can never hurt children again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, carbine poised, still lost inside himself and muttering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHALMER re-entering the front hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killing is wrong.  We only protect ourselves if we are threatened. APRIL emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about what he did to us?  We'll never be able to get on with our lives as long as we know he's somewhere out there.  We'll never feel safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorknob is turning once again.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: aiming -- the scope pressed so tight against him, it makes a deep, red imprint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragen...

dialogues.text: ARTHUR has brought out CHRISTENE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't hurt him. RAGEN looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, sweating, his eye a couple of inched from the eyepiece now.

dialogues.text: BILLY, age eight, tied to a door that's been taken off it hinges and laid across two saw horses.  CHALMER'S standin over him with a knife and a cat.  He lifts them out of frame above BILLY'S naked chest.  BILLY begins vomiting, but because of his supine position, he chokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY still sweating.

dialogues.text: The angle is such that we can't see CHALMER yet. Suddenly, he emerges.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON BILLY
dialogues.text: the trigger is slick with sweat.

dialogues.text: The Farm.  From behind, we see CHALMER is taking a leak. Once he walks away, we see that he's actually been urinating into the pipe that sticks up from the ground.

dialogues.speaker: THE PRESENT
dialogues.text: shutting and locking the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTENE has come right up to RAGEN.  She's crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragen, I'm scared.  I don't want anymore nightmares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we kill him, then they were all right.  We're crazy.  And we will never get better. RAGEN looks at CHRISTENE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... He looks at APRIL -- a woman possessed with hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHALMER turns back from locking the door and comes down the walk.

dialogues.speaker: CHALMER
dialogues.text: in BILLY'S crosshairs.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Rifle poised.

dialogues.speaker: CHALMER
dialogues.text: suddenly looks up and straight at the lens.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY'S FINGER
dialogues.text: squeezes the trigger. A SHOT RINGS OUT.

dialogues.speaker: CHALMER
dialogues.text: still alive, looks over.

dialogues.text: scatter from the treetop.

dialogues.text: leaning against the far side if the tree -- the carbine pointing straight up -- as leaves fall around him He is hyper-ventilating.

dialogues.speaker: CHALMER
dialogues.text: takes off in his car -- driving right past BILLY, but never seeing him.

dialogues.speaker: THE SPOT
dialogues.text: CHRISTENE hugging RAGEN as ARTHUR looks on and APRIL slinks back into darkness.

dialogues.text: of DANNY with CHALMER looming over him.

dialogues.text: obliterates CHALMER with his hands, as we had seen earlier, and starts to re-do the background in dark blue. This is the first time since the rapes that we've seen hi wearing a full moustache.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: at his mailbox.  The blue paint still on his fingers.

dialogues.text: as he pulls out an envelope.  Inside is an eviction notic for non-payment of rent.  He crumples it angrily.

dialogues.text: The money is gone.  The bills have not been paid.

dialogues.text: The trip to London leaves us broke. Now we are evicted.  Something must be done. PHIL and KEVIN approaches him.

dialogues.text: We can't hold a job.  We can't count on Billy to do anything.  We're starving.  There's only one way for us to make any money. KEVIN holds out a pistol to RAGEN.

dialogues.text: You don't have to hurt anyone -- just force some guy to cash a check. In the shadows, CHRISTENE is standing, holding her rag doll.  Her big blue eyes starting to dim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The same lot on the Ohio State campus where we saw BILLY abduct the women.  BILLY swigs from a bottle of vodka. He's wearing dark brown tinted sunglasses.

dialogues.text: between BILLY and various students, teachers, etc., both male and female.  He has no plan.  He's just looking for someone to rob.  He sees a young woman park a gold Toyota She gets out of the car -- it is DONNA WEST.  BILLY turns away to look elsewhere.

dialogues.text: I do not rob womans. A beat.  Behind his glasses, BILLY "blinks."

dialogues.text: Would you please get in the car? Terrified, DONNA gets in the car.  ADALANA walks around t the driver's side and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't? They turn a corner and walk smack into DICK MOLINARO and ASSISTANT ATTORNEY GENERAL BANKS, who's leading the prosecution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary.  Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Mr. Banks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You send him to Lima and you're gonna kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lima's a mental health facility, not death row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a butcher shop.  Dr. Caul talks about medical conditions and sacrificing Gods... you know what I see?  I see a little kid who had no way out, so he created a bunch of comic book heroes.  The Justice League of America.  The escape artist, the Yugoslavian hitman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rapist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one wants to make him a saint -- we just don't want to execute a guy who wasn't even there at the scene of the crimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you, Schweickart.  You don't think you're on the right side unless you feel like the underdog. Well, this time your compassion is misplaced.  Try thinking about the victims.  Try thinking about their families.  I'm gonna stop you, Gary. And I'm not gonna lose a night's sleep afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUDGE, BANKS, MOLINARO, SCHWEICKART, JUDY STEPHENSON, BILLY, HIS MOTHER, A BAILIFF and A STENOGRAPHER.  BILLY i on the stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to Lima?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  For a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when you were there, did you receive hypnotherapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Group therapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art therapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any confidence in your doctor there, Dr. Milkie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  He doesn't believe I'm sick. He gave me Stelazine.  It messed me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, before you were arrested and Dr. Caul started treating you, did you ever suspect that there was anything wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  I knew I lost time and heard voices in my head, but I thought that happened to everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you think it strange that no one talked about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so scared and embarrassed, I figured everyone else was, too. Then, every once in a while, I'd hear someone say "I don't know where the day went" or "Did I have fun last night?".  I thought that was as close as anybody came to discussing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how do you feel now, after ten months at Athens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I feel whole, like I'm one person for the first time in my life.  I used to feel like a freak. But then I got to thinkin' -- in my life, I've learned to get out of handcuffs and straitjackets, be a righty or a lefty, control if I'm drunk or sober, talk Arabic, Hebrew, Yugoslavian, Japanese, learn martial arts, play piano and drums, make my eye shake, be an artist... And, I'm no rocket scientist... my I.Q. is pretty average -- so I got to thinkin' if I could do all that, then couldn't everybody?  They just don't know how to tap into it.  But if they have a brain, just like I have a brain -- and it's made up of the same muscle and stuff that mine is, then maybe, just maybe, if they went through what I went through as a kid, they might have split up into a bunch of different people like I did.  And then I didn't feel like such a freak.  I felt like someone who got forced to open a door everybody else gets to keep locked. I felt like that but for the grace of God go there. (he turns to the Judge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hurt anybody ever again, your honor.  I can't get out of bed in the morning knowing what I've done.  But I want to keep getting better.  And I know that won't happen if you send me to Lima.

dialogues.speaker: BANKS
dialogues.text: on his feet -- delivering his summation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads from a book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Multiple Personality Disorder is a form of narcissism.  A willful disease.  Cowardly.  It is the five year old child with powdered sugar on his lips saying "I didn't eat the last doughnut." He put the book down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have already heard the testimony from his psychiatric resident at Lima State Hospital, Dr. Frederick Milkie, who, after examining the defendant, concluded not only that he did not suffer from M.P.D., but that in all probability, the disorder itself does not exist.  The defense has certainly offered no physiological evidence to the contrary.  Only differing professional opinion.  But, your honor, the validity of Mr. Milligan's psychiatric claims is not at issue here.  What is at issue is the safety of this community from a convicted sex offender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lie.  He was acquitted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right, counsel, and I apologize.  He was acquitted -- by reason of insanity. Insanity, your honor.  Insanity which made Billy Milligan strap on a Smith & Wesson, jog to the Ohio State University campus, on not one, not two, but three separate occasions, abduct a young woman, drive her to a secluded area in the woods and rape her.  And now, Dr. Caul and his staff want to allow this man, who is, by his own admission and by the court's edict, insane, to roam freely and unsupervised through the streets of this city.  Well, your honor, if this man is well and not serving very hard time, then there has been a gross miscarriage of justice.  But if he is truly insane, and not responsible for his actions at the time of the crimes, then send him to Lima, where this community can rest assured he will not be allowed to walk the streets and do yet more irreparable damage.  When you break a teacup, you glue it back together. But do you ever feel safe using it again?  No.  You put it away in the cupboard and close the door.  Your honor, there's a lot more at stake here than just being scalded by some hot water. He sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Schweickart, are you ready with your summation? GARY gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor, the prosecution is right.  There is more at stake here than just being scalded by some hot water.  There's also a hell of a lot more at stake than a cracked teacup. There's a human life.  One that's been robbed of every chance at normalcy from the age of eight by vicious and relentless child abuse. Faust made a pact with the devil. Well, Billy Milligan made a pact, too.  But he did it to survive. Something inside his eight year old mind said "I can't fight this man who adopts me, then rapes me.  Who tells me to call him Daddy, then buries me alive with just a metal pipe over my face for air.  And then urinates down the pipe.  I can't protect myself -- and neither can my mother.  And I'm too afraid to tell the police.  Or a teacher.  Because if I do, he'll kill me.  So I'll go to sleep.  And I'll let someone else take over my mind and my body to protect me.  And they can escape out of the ropes when he ties me up. And they can defend me.  And outsmart him.  And take the pain so I don't kill myself just to make it stop."  The only problem was, the personalities didn't conveniently go away when he grew up and no longer needed them.  They stayed.  And in order to fight fire with fire, some of those personalities had learned to be as angry and destructive as their tormentor.  And finally one of those personalities was a part of him who needed and demanded love. And her name was Adalana.  And three times, last October, in the woods outside Columbus, she took it.  By force.  The devil had finally come with the bill.  You've heard Dr. Caul and Dr. Harding both testify that Multiple Personality Disorder not only does exist, but that it's symptoms cannot be faked. Amnesiatic fugue states cannot be faked.  Nystagmus cannot be faked. And you've also heard them say that he's no longer a threat to himself or anybody else, but that if he's sent to Lima, where he will be given drugs instead of therapy, Billy will almost certainly re-fragment, and destroy all the remarkable progress he's made since coming to Athens. And although the prosecution has made a lot of the fact that Billy's doctors see it as essential to his recovery that he be allowed furloughs off of hospital grounds and into the city, there is a fundamental issue not being addressed here -- and that is the fact that Billy Milligan is not a criminal.  The court decided that when he was found not guilty.  And they were right to do so, We all like to think of ourselves as compassionate and caring human beings and yet as soon as that compassion threatens to demand something real from us -- a demonstration -- proof of its existence -- we draw the line. Please, your honor, let's use this opportunity to take one small step in narrowing the gap between our potential for compassion and the reality of its limits.  If I have an incurable disease, and I don't know it, and I give it to you, and you die -- can I to be tried as a murderer?  No.  I didn't know I was sick.  So you decide to quarantine me instead, which is only sensible, since we don't want me to hurt anyone else.  But, if I'm then cured to the point where I'm no longer contagious... do you never let me out again?  Billy Milligan has been fighting for his life since he was eight years old, your honor.  Now that he's finally got a piece of it back -- please don't take it away from him. GARY sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, GARY and JUDY sit waiting.  They say nothing. BILLY'S eyes move from one to the other, but they don't return the looks.  Then, a BAILIFF enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge is ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the JUDGE renders his decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The court finds that the respondent, due to his mental illness, is dangerous to himself and to others and requires hospitalization in a maximum security facility.  It is ordered, therefore, that the respondent, William Stanley Milligan, be committed to the Lima State Hospital in Lima, Ohio. He raps his gravel.  BILLY sinks into his chair, into himself.  GARY knocks his stack of papers to the floor. Outside the courtroom, there is an eruption of cheers as MOLINARO gives the thumbs up at the window.  GARY finally approaches BILLY.  They hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Billy's ear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get you out.  I swear to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY being led away in handcuffs through the crowd. Flashbulbs pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GARY and JUDY watching as BANKS and MOLINARO are interviewed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any comment, Mr. Molinaro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I have a comment.  What took them so long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO COPS shove BILLY roughly into the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got you now, motherfucker. The car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police car driving through a light drizzle.  We hear BILLY'S V.O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Gary, Billy is asleep. Something very bad is happening but I don't know what.  The doctors say bad things about us and what hurts most is they are right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up and delivers BILLY.  It is every bit as horrific as one might expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We, I, am a freak, a misfit, a biological error.  We all hate this place, but it's where we belong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he gets Billy out of the car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEN in the deepest throes of mental illness wander the corridors, some naked, as BILLY is taken to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragen is stopping everything for good.  He has to.  He says if you do not speak, you do no damage to anyone on the outside or the inside. No one can blame us for anything.

dialogues.speaker: A LINE
dialogues.text: of zombied out MEN, including BILLY, getting their Thorazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The span of attention will be turned inward and it will enforce the total block.  By shutting out the real world, we can live peacefully in ours.  We know that a world without pain is a world without feeling... but a world without feeling is a world without pain. The MAN in front of BILLY has now reached the head of the line.  He becomes upset.  He refuses the medication, screams "No!" and runs off.  BILLY steps up and takes his medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY walking aimlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm not asleep and not on the spot, it's like I'm lying face down on a street of glass that stretches out forever and I can look down through it.  Beyond that, in the farthest ground, it seems like stars of outer space, but then there's a circle.  A beam of light.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: receiving electro-shock therapy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost as if it's coming out of my eyes because it's always in front of me.  Around it, some of my people are lying in coffins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A continuation of the earlier shot: BILLY walks aimlessly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lids aren't on them because they're not dead yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOCTOR, in a suit and white lab coat, is hitting BILLY with a Bible as he's held down by ATTENDANTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rebuke you demons, in the name of the savior, Jesus Christ!  Leave this wretched soul!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're asleep, waiting for something.  There are some empty coffins because not everyone has come there yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY continues walking.  He reaches a MEN'S ROOM and looks in.  The toilets are stainless steel.  He shifts hi gaze.  The MAN who refuses his Thorazine is running the sink water at a boiling hot temperature.  He looks at BILLY through the steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and the other young ones want a chance at life.  The older ones have given up hope. The MAN puts his finger under the water -- never taking his eyes off BILLY.  The flesh quickly bubbles and boils off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny named this place because he made it. The MAN brings what's left of his digit to his mouth and bites it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He calls it "The Dying Place".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUARD throws in some paints, a brush and a piece of paper, then leaves.  BILLY picks up the paintbrush, but sets the paper aside.  He turns to the white wall and starts a mural.  It begins to segue into the Rotoscope animation -- then flowing once more into reality as it charts the accelerated progress of the painting.  Back an forth, until it's become a lush, green landscape. Idyllic, lyrical. WE PRESS IN on BILLY, in both reality and animation, as h paints, until we can no longer see the room around him -- just BILLY, enveloped in this peaceful, green Eden -- painting himself out of Hell and into a world of escape.

dialogues.speaker: LEGEND ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: Gary Schweickart appealed Billy Milligan's case to the Supreme Court.  On December 4, 1980, he was returned to Athens State Hospital, where he was successfully fused. Lima State Hospital was closed soon afterwards, amid indictments for patient abuse.

dialogues.speaker: A SECOND LEGEND REPLACES THE FIRST
dialogues.text: Today, after thirteen years in the Ohio Mental Health System.  Billy Milligan is a free man and supporting himself as an artist.
